intro: Jamesonia brunnea, commonly known as the yellow bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its showy, bell-shaped yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in moist, woodland habitats and has lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy texture. Its botanical features include a fibrous root system and a branching stem that supports its clustered inflorescence. The flowers are pollinated primarily by bees and other insects, contributing to its ecological significance in native ecosystems.
